ch5-01-phila.title: Distribution of African American inhabitants of the 7th Ward
ch5-01-phila.caption: “Distribution of African American inhabitants of the 7th Ward,” the central image of The Philadelphia Negro, which was published in 1898. In order to conduct the research for The Philadelpha Negro, Du Bois (and his wife Nina) moved to the neighborhood, where Du Bois administered social surveys and collected the other data that would culminate in the report.
ch5-01-phila.altText: A map of the seventh ward of Philadelphia. The map is about four times as wide as it is long, and its yellowed paper is worn, creased, and torn at the edges. Subdivided by street names, the Black population in this region is categorized by a color which corresponds to social condition. Red, green, blue, and black rectangles are drawn within building outlines that run along the streets of the ward. Red describes the middle and upper classes, green represents the “fair to comfortable” working class, blue describes the “poor” lower class, black represents the “vicious and criminal classes,” and the remaining white spaces, which occupy much of the map, indicate white residences, stories, public buildings, “etc..”

ch5-03-georgia.title: The Georgia Negro: A Social Study
ch5-03-georgia.caption: The introductory image of The Georgia Negro: A Social Study, the first set of charts included in the Paris Exposition
ch5-03-georgia.altText: A map of two globes showing the distribution of Black people across the world, indicated by three shades: beige, black, and brown. Several lines connect the African continent to prominent countries in North and South America, Europe, and the Caribbean along the Atlantic Slave Trade, with a lone white star depicted in the state of Georgia. The caption on the page reads: “This case is devoted to a series of charts, maps, and other devices designed to illustrate the development of the American Negro in a single typical state of the United States. ‘The problem of the 20th century is the problem of the color-line.’”
ch5-03-georgia.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33863.
ch5-03-georgia.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-03-georgia.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-04a-city.title: City and Rural Population. 1890.
ch5-04a-city.caption: City and Rural Population. 1890.
ch5-04a-city.altText: This visualization takes attributes from various chart styles to create a new form of graphing evidence for the Black population in Georgia in 1890. Beginning as a horizontal bar graph near the top of the page, a green bar indicates that there are 78,139 Black inhabitants of Georgian cities in cities whose population exceeds 10,000 people. Branching downward to the left, a small blue bar indicates 8,025 Black inhabitants live in cities whose populations are between 5,000 and 10,000 people. A longer bar branches off from the blue bar downward and to the right in a yellow color, indicating 37,699 Black inhabitants in cities whose population is between 2,500 and 5,000 people. The yellow bar connects to a red bar which spirals downward to the center of the page landing around the number 734,952, which indicates the total Black population in the country and its villages.
ch5-04a-city.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33873.
ch5-04a-city.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-04a-city.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-04b-illiteracy.title: Illiteracy.
ch5-04b-illiteracy.caption: Illiteracy.
ch5-04b-illiteracy.altText: A bar diagram of interweaving perpendicular and parallel bars that tracks illiteracy percentages of Black Georgians between 1860 and 1900 every ten years. Each year is listed from earliest to latest, top to bottom, and is connected to its corresponding illiteracy percentage by a bar that, when horizontal, is not shaded in and, when vertical, is colored in black. The four bars begin horizontally and turn downward to connect to their respective percentages, creating a criss-cross pattern. The first bar for the year 1860 measures 99 percent illiteracy in the Black Georgian population, so the horizontal portion of the bar does not extend far into the page. The bar for 1870 measures 92 percent illiteracy, thus the horizontal bar stretches farther than the previous year, but not by much. In 1880, the illiteracy percentage decreased to 81.8 percent, and in 1890, the illiteracy percentage decreased to 67.2 percent, both horizontal bars taking up more space than the previous year(s). Lastly, in 1900, the percentage of illiterate Black Georgians decreased once again to 50 percent of the population, the horizontal bar stretching the width of the chart.
ch5-04b-illiteracy.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33876.
ch5-04b-illiteracy.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-04b-illiteracy.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-04c-owners.title: Negro Property in Two Cities of Georgia.
ch5-04c-owners.caption: Negro Property in Two Cities of Georgia.
ch5-04c-owners.altText: A lattice bar chart of overlapping blue and yellow bars representing the land value and number of Black property owners in Savannah, GA (yellow) and Atlanta, GA (blue) between 1880 and 1899. The three pairs of horizontal bars show the amount of Black landowners in Savannah exceeds the amount in Atlanta, while the three pairs of vertical bars reveal that the property value in Atlanta exceeds the value in Savannah. The difference between each pair each year on the chart increases similarly, with a small difference in 1880 for both amounts measured, a more substantial difference in 1890, and a vast difference in 1899 between both the number of Black property owners and the value of property in Savannah and Atlanta.
ch5-04c-owners.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33885.
ch5-04c-owners.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-04c-owners.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-04d-value.title: Assessed Value of Household and Kitchen Furniture Owned by Georgia Negroes.
ch5-04d-value.caption: Assessed Value of Household and Kitchen Furniture Owned by Georgia Negroes.
ch5-04d-value.altText: A bar chart where six curving bars of color spiral toward the center of the page to indicate the value of household and kitchen furniture owned by Black Georgians from 1875 to 1899. The colors are all aligned in a row at the top of the page from 1875 to 1899, and each color corresponds to a year and value dollar amount. The topmost bar for 1875 is pink and is the smallest curving line, just barely beginning to curve, with the value of household furniture coming to $21,186. A blue curving bar falls just under the pink to represent 1880’s value of kitchen and household furniture, reaching $498,532. The next curving bar is brown for the year 1885 with a value of Black-owned furniture in Georgia reaching $736,170. Beneath the brown bar is a yellow curving bar for 1890, for which $1,173,624 was assessed to be the value of household and kitchen items owned by Black Georgians. The second bottom-most curving light gray bar shows that the value for Black-owned furniture in 1895 was $1,322,694. The last curving bar is red for the year 1899 and indicates that the value of household and kitchen furniture owned by Black Georgians reached $1,434,975. Each curving bar grows a bit longer than the previous bar, demonstrating the increasing value of furniture Black Georgians owned in the twenty-five years leading up to the Paris Exposition.
ch5-04d-value.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33887.
ch5-04d-value.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-04d-value.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-05a-countries.title: Negro Population in the United States Compared with the Total Popuation of Other Countries.
ch5-05a-countries.caption: Negro Population in the United States Compared with the Total Popuation of Other Countries.
ch5-05a-countries.altText: A page displaying the outlines of ten countries drawn around the United States, which lies in the center of the paper and is the only country whose shape is filled in with black ink. The countries are, going clockwise from the top right: Spain, Australia, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, England, Germany, Hungary, Belgium, and the Netherlands. The title in English heads the page, just above its French translation. The names of all countries except the U.S. are in French.
ch5-05a-countries.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33903.
ch5-05a-countries.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-05a-countries.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-05b-occupations.title: Proportion of Whites and Negroes in the different classes of occupation in the United States
ch5-05b-occupations.caption: Proportion of Whites and Negroes in the different classes of occupation in the United States
ch5-05b-occupations.altText: A circle, pinwheel-like chart that illustrates the disparity between the amount of white and Black people who worked the same occupations in the United States. The circle is outlined in red ink, while the remainder of the chart is sparse with information. Divided into six sections, progressing from the top middle section clockwise, the chart displays the ratio between those who worked in all occupations, in manufacturing and mechanical industries, trade and transportation, domestic and personal service, professions, and agriculture. In each category, six black slices remain smaller compared to the empty white space in the same category, which represents the amount of white workers in each field. The agriculture and domestic and personal service sections show a larger Black population than the other occupations due to the thicker black slices on the chart, though they still account for, at best, a fifth of the total surface area of either the agriculture or domestic service category. No key or numerical information is provided on the chart; the viewer is left to surmise the balance or imbalance of how many Black versus white people work each job based on the proportion of white space compared to black space in each section of the circle chart.
ch5-05b-occupations.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33906.
ch5-05b-occupations.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-05b-occupations.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-05c-freedom.title: The Rise of the Negroes from Slavery to Freedom in One Generation
ch5-05c-freedom.caption: The Rise of the Negroes from Slavery to Freedom in One Generation
ch5-05c-freedom.altText: A graphic of two bars comparing the number of enslaved and freed Black folk between the years 1860 and 1890. The bar located in the bottom left corner of the page shows the percentage of those enslaved and freed in 1860 and is divided into a small top section colored in green and a large section on the bottom colored in black. Bold black text within the green component of the bar indicates that 11% of the Black population was categorized as “free laborers,” while bold red text in the black portion indicates that 89% were “slaves.” The second bar, located on the right side of the page, shows the status of Black folk after Emancipation in 1890 and is divided into a small red section at the top and a larger green section that colors in the remainder of the bar. The red portion of the bar details, in black lettering, that 19% of the Black population belonged to a “peasant proprietor” class, or did not own land, while 81% of Black folk, detailed in black lettering in the green section, were tenants. The bar for 1890 is connected to the first 1860 bar by several faded, dotted lines which extend outward from one point along the right edge of the green section of the first bar to many points along the left edge of the green section of the second. The green coloring connects the two bars to indicate the amount of land-owning, free Black men and women exploded within just thirty years, or in one generation. Above the first bar and next to the second, a caption reads: “In 1890 nearly one fifth of them owned their own homes and farms. This advance was accomplished entirely without state aid, and in the face of proscriptive laws,” with a French translation of the sentences below the English text.
ch5-05c-freedom.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33912.
ch5-05c-freedom.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-05c-freedom.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-05d-newspapers.title: American Negro newspapers and periodicals.
ch5-05d-newspapers.caption: American Negro newspapers and periodicals.
ch5-05d-newspapers.altText: A multicolored pyramid that depicts the various types of writing formats in which Black people published. The tip of the pyramid is a small blue triangle, representing 3 magazines that were published. The following quadrangle is similarly small and colored in red, representing 3 daily papers that were published. The next shape is yellow and slightly larger, showing that 11 school papers were created and distributed. The next section is blue again and takes up nearly half of the pyramid, depicting that 136 weekly papers in total were published and distributed by Black publishers. The last segment of the pyramid is brown and shows the total of all Black publishing efforts, which amounted to 153 newspapers or periodicals.
ch5-05d-newspapers.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33923.
ch5-05d-newspapers.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-05d-newspapers.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-08b-amalg.title: The Amalgamation of the White and Black elements of the population in the United States.
ch5-08b-amalg.caption: The Amalgamation of the White and Black elements of the population in the United States.
ch5-08b-amalg.altText: One of 63 charts drawn by W.E.B. Du Bois and his students at Atlanta University for the Paris Exhibition held in 1900. The chart, entitled “The Amalgamation of the White and Black elements of the population in the United States,” shows the growing number of “Negro” and “mulatto” residents in the country from 1800 to 1890. Shades of black, brown, yellow, and the white of the paper represent corresponding phenotypic shades to evoke at once the racial binary between white and Black people before and after emancipation, but also to depict the fluidity and spectrum of Black identity.
ch5-08b-amalg.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33916.
ch5-08b-amalg.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-08b-amalg.notes: don't want to imbue this with interpretation...

ch5-08d-db-conjugal.title: Conjugal condition of American Negroes according to age periods.
ch5-08d-db-conjugal.caption: Conjugal condition of American Negroes according to age periods.
ch5-08d-db-conjugal.altText: Part grid and part area chart, this colorful graphic shows the marital status of Black men and women in the United States according to their age. The horizontal X axis measures the percentage (from 0 to 100%) of men and women who are single, married, or widowed, and the vertical Y axis measures age. The age increments from bottom to top, are listed as follows: 0 to 15; 15 to 20; 20 to 25; 25 to 30; 30 to 35; 35 to 45; 45 to 55; 55 to 65; and over age 65. Divided vertically in the middle, the left side of the grid tracks Black men’s marital status, and the right side measures Black women’s. Green space, which indicates widowers, occupies each top corner and falls vertically, serving as a border to the majority of the other categories; red space sits next to the green to show who is married; and blue lies in the center and along the bottom next to the red area to depict those who are single. Because of its near symmetry and vibrancy, the graphic looks like an abstract image of a city at sunset, with the central blue area resembling a silhouetted large building, and the red and green areas on either side of the blue depicting the sky.
ch5-08d-db-conjugal.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33915.
ch5-08d-db-conjugal.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-08d-db-conjugal.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-09-exhibit.title: Exposition des Nègres d'Amerique, Exposition Universelle, Paris 1900
ch5-09-exhibit.caption: A photo of the “Exposition des Nègres D'Amérique” as it was installed at the 1900 Exposition Universelle in Paris
ch5-09-exhibit.altText: A faded sepia photograph of a room in which framed maps, graphs, collages, and portraits line the walls above full bookcases. Above the ceiling’s crown molding, the title “Exposition des Nègres D’Amérique” is written on a plaque, and the sign for the Paris Exposition rests just below, which reads, “Exposition Universelle, Paris 1900, Grand Prix.”
ch5-09-exhibit.creditLine: Image courtesy of Special Collections and University Archives, University of Massachusetts Amherst Libraries.

ch5-11-property.title: Assessed Valuation of All Taxable Property Owned by Georgia Negroes.
ch5-11-property.caption: Assessed Valuation of All Taxable Property Owned by Georgia Negroes.
ch5-11-property.altText: A nested circle chart resembling a bull’s-eye that shows the valuation of all taxable Black-owned property in Georgia between the years 1875-1900. The innermost circle is black with white numbering that shows, in 1875, the valuation of taxable Black-owned Georgian property was $5,393,885. The ring surrounding the black circle is brown and shows the valuation of taxable Black-owned property in 1880 was $5,764,293. The next outermost ring is thicker and blue, indicating an increase in taxable property in 1885 to $8,153,390. An even thicker yellow ring surrounds the blue, showing $12,322,003 in 1890. The second outermost ring is smaller and gray and indicates the valuation in 1895 to be $12,941,230. The final outermost circle is red, similarly thin, and shows that the valuation of all taxable Black-owned property in Georgia in 1899 reached $13,447,423. The circle chart is drawn so that each ring has a protruding triangle or point that reaches inward to the 1870 black center. With each overlapping circle, the intrusive triangles become thicker and are overlaid by the other rings’s colors, creating a hypnotic effect as if each circle is being torn back to reveal the black center, emphasized by each triangle’s jagged edges.
ch5-11-property.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33884.
ch5-11-property.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-11-property.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

ch5-12-series.title: A series of statistical charts illustrating the condition of the descendants of former African slaves now in residence in the United States of America
ch5-12-series.caption: A series of statistical charts illustrating the condition of the descendants of former African slaves now in residence in the United States of America
ch5-12-series.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-08994.
ch5-12-series.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
ch5-12-series.notes: Included later so don't include this copy

925.title: Statistics of Negro church organizations.
925.caption: Statistics of Negro church organizations.
925.altText: A spare bar chart of various statistics relating to Black religious organizing. The topmost bar stretches most of the page’s width to show the 23,462 church organizations in the country. The second bar depicts the number of church edifices, which runs the entire width of the page and comes to 23,770 buildings. The next statistic is a monetary amount rather than a bar, set in a bold font, to claim the total value of these church properties, which is written as $26,626,448 or 137,960,860 francs. The last bar at the bottom of the page, which runs the entire width of the page, represents the 2,673,977 communicants who run, organize, and attend these religious events. For reference, underneath the communicants bar, a smaller bar shows the population of New York in comparison, which reaches about three-fourths of the length depicting Black communicants.
925.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
925.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

923.title: American Negro newspapers and periodicals.
923.caption: American Negro newspapers and periodicals.
923.altText: A multicolored pyramid that depicts the various types of writing formats in which Black people published. The tip of the pyramid is a small blue triangle, representing 3 magazines that were published. The following quadrangle is similarly small and colored in red, representing 3 daily papers that were published. The next shape is yellow and slightly larger, showing that 11 school papers were created and distributed. The next section is blue again and takes up nearly half of the pyramid, depicting that 136 weekly papers in total were published and distributed by Black publishers. The last segment of the pyramid is brown and shows the total of all Black publishing efforts, which amounted to 153 newspapers or periodicals.
923.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33923.
923.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

888.title: Occupations of Georgia Negroes. Males over 10.
888.caption: Occupations of Georgia Negroes. Males over 10.
888.altText: A horizontal bar chart showing various occupations that Black men over 10 years of age worked in 1890 and the corresponding amount of workers per occupation. The number of workers per occupation diminishes as the list goes down. The top occupation indicates that 98,400 men worked as agricultural laborers, and the red bar rounds to show the mass of people employed in this category. The number of workers in the next category, farmers and planters, amounts to 63,012 people, and the bar stretches the width of the paper. Following the first two occupations, the number per category goes down significantly, with 29,732 men working as generic “laborers,” 7,440 men working as steam railway employees, 7,000 working as servants, 4,390 as draymen or hackmen, and 3,761 working as carpenters and joiners. After these top individual jobs are noted, the remaining fifteen jobs (from 2,471 men who work at sawmills to the last category of 519 men who work as gardeners and florists) are combined into one bar that is about half the size of the laborers category.
888.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33888.
888.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

879.title: Number of Negro students taking the various courses of study offered in Georgia schools.
879.caption: Number of Negro students taking the various courses of study offered in Georgia schools.
879.altText: A bar chart detailing various areas of study that are offered in Georgia’s schools and how many Black students are enrolled in each. The courses of study are labeled as the following, from top to bottom with a growing number of students in each subsequent category: business, classical, professional, scientific, normal, and industrial. The number of students in the industrial category is much larger than the others, amounting to 2,252 students, whereas the number of students taking courses from business to normal goes from 12 students to 383, respectively. To demonstrate the volume of students studying industrial arts, the bar extends the length of the page and curves downward twice so the bar may continue to run horizontally.
879.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33879.
879.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

884.title: Assessed Valuation of All Taxable Property Owned by Georgia Negroes.
884.caption: Assessed Valuation of All Taxable Property Owned by Georgia Negroes.
884.altText: A nested circle chart resembling a bull’s-eye that shows the valuation of all taxable Black-owned property in Georgia between the years 1875-1900. The innermost circle is black with white numbering that shows, in 1875, the valuation of taxable Black-owned Georgian property was $5,393,885. The ring surrounding the black circle is brown and shows the valuation of taxable Black-owned property in 1880 was $5,764,293. The next outermost ring is thicker and blue, indicating an increase in taxable property in 1885 to $8,153,390. An even thicker yellow ring surrounds the blue, showing $12,322,003 in 1890. The second outermost ring is smaller and gray and indicates the valuation in 1895 to be $12,941,230. The final outermost circle is red, similarly thin, and shows that the valuation of all taxable Black-owned property in Georgia in 1899 reached $13,447,423. The circle chart is drawn so that each ring has a protruding triangle or point that reaches inward to the 1870 black center. With each overlapping circle, the intrusive triangles become thicker and are overlaid by the other rings’s colors, creating a hypnotic effect as if each circle is being torn back to reveal the black center, emphasized by each triangle’s jagged edges.
884.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33884.
884.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

899.title: A series of statistical charts illustrating the condition of the descendants of former African slaves now in residence in the United States of America
899.caption: A series of statistical charts illustrating the condition of the descendants of former African slaves now in residence in the United States of America
899.altText: The first chart in the second series presented at the Paris Exposition is dense with text in both English and French to highlight the history and role of Atlanta University students–and the institution itself–in creating the data portraits. The text describes the year the college was founded (1867), the total number of Black students who have attended the university (6,000 at the time of the study), and the total number of graduates from the university (330 students) who have since gone on to work in various fields described in a pie chart. The multicolor pie chart sits in the middle of the page describing employment and other conditions of Black Americans with a key in English to the left and in French to the right of the chart. The largest section of the pie chart is colored in red and records that 58.5 percent of the Black American population works as teachers. The second largest portion of the chart is yellow and shows 28.1 percent of the population is designated as house wives. Decreasing substantially in size to 4.3 percent is the next population of Black American employees who work as ministers, indicated in blue. Other professions and government service follow at 3.8 and 3.2 percent respectively, with other professions colored in green and government service in pink. The smallest portion of Black American employment is under the category of business, which is shaded in light brown and is recorded at 2.1 percent. A small multicolored map of the United States also rests under the title of the piece with a star over Atlanta, GA to indicate the center of the Black population in the country. More text at the bottom of the page states the number of current Black professors, faculty, and students at Atlanta University at the time of the study (20 professors and faculty; 250 students), along with a description of the size of the campus (60 acres) and number of buildings (5), including the library which holds 11,000 volumes. Lastly, the text describes the university’s endowment of $500,000 and the mission of the university, which is “to raise and civilize the songs of the freedmen by training their more capable members in the liberal arts according to the best standards of the day.”
899.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-08994.
899.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

863.title: The Georgia Negro: A Social Study
863.caption: The Georgia Negro: A Social Study
863.altText: A map of two globes showing the distribution of Black people across the world, indicated by three shades: beige, black, and brown. Several lines connect the African continent to prominent countries in North and South America, Europe, and the Caribbean along the Atlantic Slave Trade, with a lone white star depicted in the state of Georgia. The caption on the page reads: “This case is devoted to a series of charts, maps, and other devices designed to illustrate the development of the American Negro in a single typical state of the United States. ‘The problem of the 20th century is the problem of the color-line.’”
863.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33863.
863.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

864.title: Relative Negro population of the states of the United States.
864.caption: Relative Negro population of the states of the United States.
864.altText: A map of the United States in which states are differentiated according to various colors depending on the size of each state’s Black population. Bright primary colors darken to cross-hatched, shaded areas and solid browns and blacks in the states where the number grows.
864.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33864.
864.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

865.title: The states of the United States according to their Negro population.
865.caption: The states of the United States according to their Negro population.
865.altText: A horizontal bar chart of the Black population within the United States broken down by state. The topmost bar, Georgia, has the largest Black population (858,815), while Pennsylvania, the second to last bar from the bottom, has the smallest population of the named states (107,596). Underneath Pennsylvania, the last bar is labeled as the Black population for all remaining states, coming to 608,340 people. The other named states between Georgia and Pennsylvania, progressively getting smaller as the list goes on, are: Mississippi, South Carolina, Alabama, Virginia, North Carolina, Louisiana, Texas, Tennessee, Arkansas, Kentucky, Maryland, Florida, and Missouri.
865.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
865.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

866.title: Negro population of Georgia.
866.caption: Negro population of Georgia.
866.altText: A horizontal bar chart depicting the growing Black population in Georgia every ten years from 1790 to 1890. The size grows steadily from top to bottom, going from 107,019 people in 1790 to 858,815 in 1890.
866.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33866.
866.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

867.title: Negro population of Georgia by counties. 1890.
867.caption: Negro population of Georgia by counties. 1890.
867.altText: A colorful map of Georgia in 1890 subdivided and color-coordinated by the size of each county’s Black population. Bright pinks and yellows dominate and spread throughout the map, while clusters of dark blue, brown, and green are concentrated on specific areas within Georgia’s borders. A key at the bottom of the page shows which colors correspond to which population size range.
867.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33867.
867.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

868.title: Negro population of Georgia by counties.
868.caption: Negro population of Georgia by counties.
868.altText: Two colorful maps of Georgia subdivided and color-coordinated by the size of each county’s Black population. The map on the top left depicts Black population by county in the year 1870, and the map on the bottom right depicts Black population by county in the year 1880. Both are dominated by pink and yellow, which show population sizes between 1,000 to 10,000 people. A key indicating population size is listed on the top right quadrant and bottom left quadrant of the page, containing the same values as the previous map of Georgia in 1890.
868.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33868.
868.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

869.title: Comparative increase of white and colored population of Georgia.
869.caption: Comparative increase of white and colored population of Georgia.
869.altText: A line chart showing the rate of Black and white population growth in Georgia between 1790 and 1890. A solid black line tracks the Black population size and a dotted black line tracks the white population size. The vertical Y axis measures the year in increments of ten years, and the horizontal X axis measures percentage of population growth.
869.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33869.
869.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

870.title: Migration of Negroes. 1890.
870.caption: Migration of Negroes. 1890.
870.altText: Two colorful maps of the United States in 1890 showing the number of Black people with connections to Georgia in each state. The top map depicts the migration of Black people born in Georgia to their residencies in other states, and the bottom map depicts the states in which Black people were born who moved to Georgia and reside there as of 1890. Georgia is the only state colored in with black ink to make it stand out. Arrows in the top map point away from Georgia to showcase movement out of the state, whereas arrows in the bottom map point toward Georgia to showcase movement into the state.
870.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33870
870.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

871.title: Age distribution of Georgia Negroes compared with France.
871.caption: Age distribution of Georgia Negroes compared with France.
871.altText: A yellow and black horizontal bar chart comparing the ages of Black Georgians to people of all races in France. Ages are divided by ten years, going from people under ten years of age at the top of the page to seventy and above at the bottom of the page. Georgia has a higher percentage of Black people under 30, whereas France has a higher percentage of people over 30.
871.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33871.
871.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

872.title: Conjugal condition.
872.caption: Conjugal condition.
872.altText: 3 pairs of tricolored bar charts comparing the marital status of Black Americans and people from Germany, divided by age group. The color red indicates the percentage of the population that is single, yellow indicates married, and green indicates widowed or divorced. The top chart of each pair depicts Germans, and the bottom of each pair depicts Black Americans. The first pair of charts shows the marital status between the ages of 15 through 40, the second pair between 40 and 60 years old, and the last pair 60 and over.
872.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33872.
872.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

873.title: City and Rural Population. 1890.
873.caption: City and Rural Population. 1890.
873.altText: This visualization takes attributes from various chart styles to create a new form of graphing evidence for the Black population in Georgia in 1890. Beginning as a horizontal bar graph near the top of the page, a green bar indicates that there are 78,139 Black inhabitants of Georgian cities in cities whose population exceeds 10,000 people. Branching downward to the left, a small blue bar indicates 8,025 Black inhabitants live in cities whose populations are between 5,000 and 10,000 people. A longer bar branches off from the blue bar downward and to the right in a yellow color, indicating 37,699 Black inhabitants in cities whose population is between 2,500 and 5,000 people. The yellow bar connects to a red bar which spirals downward to the center of the page landing around the number 734,952, which indicates the total Black population in the country and its villages.
873.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33873.
873.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

874.title: Slaves and free Negroes.
874.caption: Slaves and free Negroes.
874.altText: A red and black chart showing the number of enslaved Africans compared to the number of free Black people in Georgia from 1790 to 1870. Time measured in increments of ten years vertically lines the left side of the chart while the percentage of free Black Georgians vertically lines the right side. The enslaved population is depicted with black ink and the free population is depicted with red ink, and the two colors clash in the middle of the chart veering between 1.7 and 0.7 percent freed, until the years between 1860 and 1870 where the red takes over the bottom of the chart, indicating a 100 percent free Black population in Georgia.
874.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33874.
874.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

875.title: Race amalgamation in Georgia based on a study of 40,000 individuals of Negro descent.
875.caption: Race amalgamation in Georgia based on a study of 40,000 individuals of Negro descent.
875.altText: A chart detailing the race amalgamation–or racial ancestry–of Black individuals in Georgia. Based on a study of 40,000 individuals, as the subtitle says, the chart vertically divides the race into three categories: the top, colored in black, is labeled “black” or “full-blooded Negroes”; the second, colored in brown, is labeled “brown” or “persons with some white blood or descendents of light colored Africans”; and the third, colored in yellow, is labeled “yellow” or “persons with more white than Negro blood.” The “black” population makes up 44 percent of all Black people in Georgia, the “brown” population makes up 40 percent, and the percentage of “yellow” individuals is 16 percent.
875.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33875.
875.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

876.title: Illiteracy.
876.caption: Illiteracy.
876.altText: A bar diagram of interweaving perpendicular and parallel bars that tracks illiteracy percentages of Black Georgians between 1860 and 1900 every ten years. Each year is listed from earliest to latest, top to bottom, and is connected to its corresponding illiteracy percentage by a bar that, when horizontal, is not shaded in and, when vertical, is colored in black. The four bars begin horizontally and turn downward to connect to their respective percentages, creating a criss-cross pattern. The first bar for the year 1860 measures 99 percent illiteracy in the Black Georgian population, so the horizontal portion of the bar does not extend far into the page. The bar for 1870 measures 92 percent illiteracy, thus the horizontal bar stretches farther than the previous year, but not by much. In 1880, the illiteracy percentage decreased to 81.8 percent, and in 1890, the illiteracy percentage decreased to 67.2 percent, both horizontal bars taking up more space than the previous year(s). Lastly, in 1900, the percentage of illiterate Black Georgians decreased once again to 50 percent of the population, the horizontal bar stretching the width of the chart.
876.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33876.
876.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

877.title: Negro children enrolled in the public schools.
877.caption: Negro children enrolled in the public schools.
877.altText: A green bar chart depicting an increasing number of Black children enrolled in public schools in Georgia between the years 1860 and 1897. The vertical bars grow rapidly from 7 children in 1860 to 10,351 in 1870 and again to 72,655 children in 1878. The amount of children enrolled in public schools continues to increase gradually after 1878, culminating to 180,565 children in 1897.
877.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33877.
877.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

878.title: Negro teachers in Georgia public schools.
878.caption: Negro teachers in Georgia public schools.
878.altText: A chart depicting the number of Black teachers who worked in Georgia’s public schools from 1886 to 1897. Four circles vertically aligned change color and shift in size depending on the population of Black teachers in Georgia, indicated by the number located in the center of each circle. The top circle is gray and shows 2,512 Black teachers in 1886; the second circle is yellow and shows 2,500 teachers in 1889; the third circle is red and shows 3,206 teachers in 1893; and the final, largest circle is blue and shows that there were 3,316 Black teachers in 1897 who worked in Georgia’s public schools.
878.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33878.
878.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

880.title: Value of land owned by Georgia Negroes.
880.caption: Value of land owned by Georgia Negroes.
880.altText: A pictographic chart where six brown bags of money grow in size from top to bottom. Each burlap sack is labeled with a year and monetary value. For instance, the top bag shows the value of land owned by Black Georgians in 1875 was $1,263,902. The bottommost, largest bag shows that the value of land owned by Black Georgian in 1899 amounted to $4,220,120.
880.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33880.
880.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

881.title: Acres of land owned by Negroes in Georgia.
881.caption: Acres of land owned by Negroes in Georgia.
881.altText: A red bar chart showing the number of acres owned by Black people in Georgia between the years 1874 and 1899 (with an exception for year 1881, which is absent). The bars grow steadily from 338,769 acres of land in 1874 to 1,062,223 acres in 1899. The amount of acres is highest in 1898, though no numerical value is given for this bar.
881.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33881.
881.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

882.title: Land owned by Negroes in Georgia, U.S.A. 1870-1900.
882.caption: Land owned by Negroes in Georgia, U.S.A. 1870-1900.
882.altText: A multicolored map of Georgia depicting the number of acres of land per county owned by Black residents between the years 1870 and 1900. There is no key to detail color coordination to acre size, with the exception of a small caption to the side of the map that reads, “the figures indicate the number of acres owned in each county in 1899.”
882.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33882.
882.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

883.title: Valuation of town and city property owned by Georgia Negroes.
883.caption: Valuation of town and city property owned by Georgia Negroes.
883.altText: A line graph overlaid on a red grid of squares measuring the value of Black-owned property in Georgia from 1870 to 1900. The vertical Y axis tracks monetary value by the million dollar, and the horizontal X axis measures the year, where every grid box along the X axis is one year. The line moves diagonally up to the right with peaks in 1872 and 1883 (measured around 1 million and 5 million dollars respectively) before slight dips in monetary value. Between 1879 and 1883, the value of Black-owned property in Georgia increased from just above one million dollars to nearly five million. Dispersed around the line are descriptions of the political atmosphere of the time. For instance, between 1870 and 1872, Du Bois and his affiliates wrote vertically, parallel to the increase in property value, “Ku-Kluxism,” indicating the rise of the Ku Klux Klan. Above the line around the 2.5 million dollar mark before the subsequent decade of the 1880s, another descriptor reads “Political Unrest.” Below the line between the years 1890 and 1895 and below the two million dollar mark, one descriptor is written vertically that says, “Financial panic,” and another above the latter is written horizontally: “Lynching.” The last description on the grid mirrors the “Political Unrest” label on the other side of the line, which reads: “Disenfranchisement and Proscriptive Laws.”
883.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33883.
883.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

885.title: Negro property in two cities of Georgia.
885.caption: Negro property in two cities of Georgia.
885.altText: A lattice bar chart of overlapping blue and yellow bars representing the land value and number of Black property owners in Savannah, GA (yellow) and Atlanta, GA (blue) between 1880 and 1899. The three pairs of horizontal bars show the amount of Black landowners in Savannah exceeds the amount in Atlanta, while the three pairs of vertical bars reveal that the property value in Atlanta exceeds the value in Savannah. The difference between each pair each year on the chart increases similarly, with a small difference in 1880 for both amounts measured, a more substantial difference in 1890, and a vast difference in 1899 between both the number of Black property owners and the value of property in Savannah and Atlanta.
885.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33885.
885.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

886.title: Value of farming tools.
886.caption: Value of farming tools.
886.altText: A horizontal bar chart showing how the value of farm tools increased and decreased between the years 1879 and 1898. There are no monetary values assigned to the brown-colored bars; the bars only increase and decrease in relation to each other. The five bars correspond to years, from top to bottom, 1879, 1883, 1888, 1893, and 1899.
886.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33886.
886.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

887.title: Assessed Value of Household and Kitchen Furniture Owned by Georgia Negroes.
887.caption: Assessed Value of Household and Kitchen Furniture Owned by Georgia Negroes.
887.altText: A bar chart where six curving bars of color spiral toward the center of the page to indicate the value of household and kitchen furniture owned by Black Georgians from 1875 to 1899. The colors are all aligned in a row at the top of the page from 1875 to 1899, and each color corresponds to a year and value dollar amount. The topmost bar for 1875 is pink and is the smallest curving line, just barely beginning to curve, with the value of household furniture coming to $21,186. A blue curving bar falls just under the pink to represent 1880’s value of kitchen and household furniture, reaching $498,532. The next curving bar is brown for the year 1885 with a value of Black-owned furniture in Georgia reaching $736,170. Beneath the brown bar is a yellow curving bar for 1890, for which $1,173,624 was assessed to be the value of household and kitchen items owned by Black Georgians. The second bottom-most curving light gray bar shows that the value for Black-owned furniture in 1895 was $1,322,694. The last curving bar is red for the year 1899 and indicates that the value of household and kitchen furniture owned by Black Georgians reached $1,434,975. Each curving bar grows a bit longer than the previous bar, demonstrating the increasing value of furniture Black Georgians owned in the twenty-five years leading up to the Paris Exposition.
887.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33887.
887.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

889.title: Occupations of Negroes and whites in Georgia.
889.caption: Occupations of Negroes and whites in Georgia.
889.altText: A circle chart depicting five groups of occupations and the percentages of Black and white Georgians who work them. The top half of the circle is dedicated to Black laborers, and the bottom half to white laborers. The largest portion of each population is red and belongs to agriculture, fishing, and mining industries. 62 percent of Black Georgians worked in this field, as did 64 percent of white Georgians. Next to the red portion is a yellow section of the circle indicating those who work in domestic or personal service. The percentage for Black Georgians is 28 percent, while for white Georgians it is only 5.5 percent. Next, a blue segment of the circle indicates manufacturing and mechanical industrial jobs, where 5 percent of the Black population and 13.5 percent of the white population work. A light gray portion follows to depict trade and transportation occupations, with 13 percent of white Georgians and 4.5 percent of Black Georgians working those jobs. Lastly, a small brown portion indicates only 4 percent of white Georgians and less than 1 percent of Black Georgians work other generalized “professions.”
889.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33889.
889.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

890.title: Occupations.
890.caption: Occupations.
890.altText: A table filled in with handwritten values of the weekly wages, annual income, and hours per day that Georgians worked various occupations. The sheet is filled out with graphite and the writing is faded.
890.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33890.
890.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

891.title: Occupations and income.
891.caption: Occupations and income.
891.altText: A handwritten table of occupations and wages made by Black Georgians according to their sex, as well as the income of Black families in Georgia. The handwriting, done in pencil, is faded and much of the table is blank.
891.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33891.
891.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

892.title: Condition of 300 Negro farm tenants after 1 year's toil, 1898.
892.caption: Condition of 300 Negro farm tenants after 1 year's toil, 1898.
892.altText: A horizontal bar chart that shows the number of Black Georgian farmers and how much money they did or did not make after a year of labor. Two black bars top the chart, one small and one large, to represent 3 farmers who went bankrupt and 168 who were in debt in 1898. The next five bars are red and decrease in size based on how much money the farmers cleared–from nothing to $50 or more. Each red bar is then combined to amount to 121 farmers, still smaller than the black bar above indicating 168 farmers in debt.
892.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33892.
892.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

893.title: Income and expenditure of 150 Negro families in Atlanta, Ga., U.S.A.
893.caption: Income and expenditure of 150 Negro families in Atlanta, Ga., U.S.A.
893.altText: A mixed media chart that indicates how Black Georgian families from various class backgrounds make and spend their money. The visualization combines inked typography, photograph, colored charts, mechanical type, and a gold-plated seal of one American dollar. Organized vertically into categories based on family income, the subcategories along the horizontal X axis top the chart to list the cost of rent, food, clothing, taxes, and other expenses and savings. These categories connect to a bar chart that shows the percentage of how much the various classes of Black families spend on each expense. Each expense includes a brief explanatory note or image below it to provide detail about what the percentages refer to. For instance, under “rent,” there is a photograph of a four houses lined up on a street that Du Bois’ team labels a “well-to-do neighborhood.” Similarly, under “clothes,” two portraits of a young Black boy and a Black woman are present. The other three expenses include worded descriptions, like the “other expenses and savings” category, which lists what the team terms “the higher life,” including items like religion, art, amusements, books, and travel. Under each expense description or image, a bar of black, purple, pink, blue, or gray lies to help indicate the percentages of expenses given to each category in the chart. Every income bracket except for the last is paired with the one above it, where those families bringing in $139.10-$249.45 yearly are classified as “poor,” those making $335.86-$433.82 are deemed “fair,” those making $547-$880 are “comfortable,” and finally, the last separate category, those who make $1,125 yearly are “well-to-do.”
893.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33893.
893.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

894.title: Family budgets.
894.caption: Family budgets.
894.altText: A table showing the different budgets for Black families depending on the head of household’s occupation. The tables begin with the laborers who make the least–firemen and engineers at $312–and ends with those who make the most–painters, bringing in $540. The other occupations in between include, in order, sash and blind makers ($360), carpenters ($360), rock masons ($375), wheelwrights ($450), barbers ($400), and blacksmiths ($450). Each table breaks down how much money is allocated to various expenses, though each sheet is filled out in different styles of penmanship, implying a multiplicity of people contributing to the work.
894.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33894.
894.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

895.title: Family budgets.
895.caption: Family budgets.
895.altText: A table that shows the same information as the previous Family Budgets chart with a layer of brown paper stuck to the board, obstructing the data’s view. The pencil-sketched titles and headlines indicate a draft version of the previous table.
895.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33895.
895.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

896.title: Albany, Dougherty County, Ga. Distribution of 2,500 Negro inhabitants.
896.caption: Albany, Dougherty County, Ga. Distribution of 2,500 Negro inhabitants.
896.altText: A map of the class distribution in Black communities of Albany, Georgia, a city within Dougherty County. To the right, a drawing of a river borders the county line, and various colored dots indicate four class categories. According to Du Bois and his team, the classes represented are described as follows in a scripted hand: red dots signal “well-to-do” inhabitants, green shows the “better class for laborers,” blue indicates the “poor” class, black is for the “lowest class,” and yellow (listed off to the side in brackets) is to differentiate the white residences. Clusters of predominantly blue, black, and yellow concentrate in the middle of the grid where the bulk of the city’s population resides, while on the outskirts less frequent dots are gathered. On the periphery of the grid to the left, a small cluster of red, green, and blue dots linger.
896.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33896.
896.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

897.title: McIntosh County, Georgia.
897.caption: McIntosh County, Georgia.
897.altText: A map of McIntosh County, Georgia that shows color-coded dots corresponding to racial and class divisions. Red dots indicate “well-to-do” Black inhabitants, green dots indicate “better class of laborers and small farmers,” blue dots indicate “poor,” and black dots indicate “lowest class.” A sub-category for the “approximate distribution of whites” is indicated by yellow dots. This map shows a wider view than the grid of Albany, GA, taking into account different rivers, roads, and railways.
897.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33897.
897.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

898.title: Darien, McIntosh Co., GA
898.caption: Darien, McIntosh Co., GA
898.altText: A map of Darien, GA, a city within McIntosh County, that depicts the distribution of 1,000 Black inhabitants. Drawn diagonally and up-close to show the streets of the city, four color-coded dots fill in the grid: red dots correspond to “well-to-do” inhabitants, green symbolizes the “better class of laborers,” blue indicates the “poor,” and black depicts the “lowest class.” A curving river colored in a light green borders the bottom and left sides of the town.
898.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33898.
898.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

900.title: Distribution of Negroes in the United States.
900.caption: Distribution of Negroes in the United States.
900.altText: A map of the United States displaying a color-coded distribution of Black inhabitants across the nation. Under the title and its French translation, a key showing five circles of colors indicates increasing population density in the following order: the color yellow represents less than one Black resident per square mile, blue represents between one and four Black inhabitants per square mile, red represents between four and eight residents per square mile, brown represents between eight and fifteen inhabitants per square mile, and the color black indicates between fifteen and twenty-five Black residents per square mile. The majority of the west side of the country is yellow, whereas Texas and several midwestern states are shaded blue. Southeastern states are primarily colored as brown, except for South Carolina and Mississippi, which are black. There are infrequent spots of no coloring at all–right above Texas where Oklahoma and Arkansas meet, as well as off the coast of New York, both of which occur nearby red, yellow, and blue shading rather than brown or black.
900.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
900.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

901.title: Increase of the Negro population in the United States of America
901.caption: Increase of the Negro population in the United States of America
901.altText: A bar chart showing the growing Black population in the United States from 1750 to 1890. Each bar is red and represents the Black population’s size every ten years, with 220,000 individuals accounted for beginning in 1750 to 7,470,040 people in 1890. The type indicating the year and size of the Black population is bold compared to the lighter type of the title and French translation at the top of the page. The subtitle of the chart reads, “Done by Atlanta University” to credit the students who worked with Du Bois.
901.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
901.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

902.title: Comparative rate of increase of the white and Negro elements of the population of the United States
902.caption: Comparative rate of increase of the white and Negro elements of the population of the United States
902.altText: A line chart comparing the white population to the Black population in the United States between 1790 and 1890. The horizontal X axis tracks the population every ten years, and the vertical Y axis measures the population by five million. The Black population is represented by a red line, which remains far below the green line representing the white population. Between 1790 and 1890, the difference in population between the two racial groups grew exponentially; both the white and Black populations began in 1790 under the five million mark and rose to more than fifty million people (white) versus merely seven million (Black) by 1890. The chart also depicts various international and national events in a fainter text across the graph, like the “suppression of slave trade” in 1810, “European immigration” placed between 1840 and 1850, and “Emancipation” between 1860 and 1870, in slightly larger lettering than the previous events. The key on the graph, aside from describing how each population corresponds to the two line colors, notes that the small numbers which lie above the two lines indicate the percentage increase per decade of each population. The page also shows wear along the right edge due to damage, caused either by fire or water.
902.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
902.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

903.title: Negro Population in the United States Compared with the Total Popuation of Other Countries.
903.caption: Negro Population in the United States Compared with the Total Popuation of Other Countries.
903.altText: A page displaying the outlines of ten countries drawn around the United States, which lies in the center of the paper and is the only country whose shape is filled in with black ink. The countries are, going clockwise from the top right: Spain, Australia, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland, England, Germany, Hungary, Belgium, and the Netherlands. The title in English heads the page, just above its French translation. The names of all countries except the U.S. are in French.
903.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33903.
903.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

904.title: Proportion of Negroes in the total population of the United States
904.caption: Proportion of Negroes in the total population of the United States
904.altText: Four outlines of the United States growing in size every thirty years from top to bottom, left to right. Within each outline drawn in red, another smaller silhouette of the country is shaded in black to depict the smaller Black population in comparison to the total population of the United States. Every thirty years, from 1800 to 1890, the size of the map outlined in red grows, but the size of the Black population diminishes. In 1800, the Black population is captioned as making up one-fifth of the country’s population. In 1830, the Black population decreased to one-sixth of the total population, and similarly for 1860 and 1890, where the Black population made up one-seventh and then one-eighth of the total U.S population, respectively. All the while, each map outlined in red grows to take up a larger portion of the page. The text indicating the proportion of the Black population is green, while the years are set in a bold black font.
904.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
904.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

905.title: Occupations in which American Negroes are engaged
905.caption: Occupations in which American Negroes are engaged
905.altText: A graphic of three vertical bars that compares various professions Black Georgians engaged in according to their sex. The three bars are each divided into five colors: from top to bottom, the red fragment of the bars represents those who work in agriculture, mining and fishing; blue represents those who work in the vague category of “professions''; yellow shows the amount of Black Georgians who work in domestic and personal service; brown shows commerce and ground transportation; and the bottom fragment of each bar is green, representing manufacturing and mechanical industries. The length of each colored segment corresponds to the amount of workers in each category; the longer the colored segment in each bar, the greater the number of workers. The leftmost bar depicts how many Black Georgians of both sexes worked per category, the middle bar depicts how many males worked per category, and the rightmost bar depicts how many females worked in each occupation. To the left of the bars, each category is described in English, and to the right, the occupations are written in French. The largest segment of the middle bar is red, indicating that Black men worked predominantly in mines, agriculture, and fishing. The largest color on the rightmost graph is yellow, indicating that Black women worked predominantly in domestic and personal service. The red and yellow segments are the two largest pieces of each bar, and the blue segments for “professions” are the smallest, except for females, where the category colored in brown for commerce and transportation service is just as small.
905.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
905.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

906.title: Proportion of Whites and Negroes in the different classes of occupation in the United States
906.caption: Proportion of Whites and Negroes in the different classes of occupation in the United States
906.altText: A pinwheel-like circle chart that illustrates the disparity between the amount of white and Black people who worked the same occupations in the United States. The circle is outlined in red ink, while the remainder of the chart is sparse with information. Divided into six sections, progressing from the top middle section clockwise, the chart displays the ratio between those who worked in all occupations, in manufacturing and mechanical industries, trade and transportation, domestic and personal service, professions, and agriculture. In each category, six black slices remain smaller compared to the empty white space in the same category, which represents the amount of white workers in each field. The agriculture and domestic and personal service sections show a larger Black population than the other occupations due to the thicker black slices on the chart, though they still account for, at best, a fifth of the total surface area of either the agriculture or domestic service category. No key or numerical information is provided on the chart; the viewer is left to surmise the balance or imbalance of how many Black versus white people work each job based on the proportion of white space compared to black space in each section of the circle chart.
906.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33906.
906.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

907.title: Occupations in which 10,000 or more American Negroes are engaged
907.caption: Occupations in which 10,000 or more American Negroes are engaged
907.altText: A horizontal bar chart showing over 10,000 Black workers who engaged in various occupations in the United States. The top red bar indicating agriculture laborers stretches across the page, and the number of workers, which is 1,106,728, sits on top of the bar. The following category of farmers decreases nearly to half the amount of agricultural workers. Servants, laborers, and launderers and laundresses follow, decreasing steadily in amount one after the other until the bar for launderers and laundresses extends approximately a seventh of the length of agriculture laborers. The bars shorten substantially for the remaining occupations, which when put together amount to 10,500 workers: railroad employees, draymen, carpenters, barbers, sawmill employees, porters, teachers, tobacco factory operatives, clergymen, other agricultural pursuits, seamstresses, blacksmiths, brickmakers, and hostlers.
907.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
907.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

908.title: Number of Negro teachers in the public schools of the United States
908.caption: Number of Negro teachers in the public schools of the United States
908.altText: A yellow bar chart showing the growing number of Black teachers who worked at public schools in the United States between the years 1886 to 1895. Only four bars are drawn to represent the number of teachers employed in public schools every three years (1886 to 1895, top to bottom), though no numerical data of the actual number of teachers is shown. The lack of information emphasizes that, while the number of Black teachers increased between the nine years present, the rate of growth slowed each subsequent set of three years.
908.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
908.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

909.title: Illiteracy of the American Negroes compared with that of other nations.
909.caption: Illiteracy of the American Negroes compared with that of other nations.
909.altText: A horizontal bar chart comparing the illiteracy rate of Black Americans to other countries in the Paris Exposition. Black American illiteracy is the only bar colored in red, and it lands as the fourth country listed on the chart, while all other bars are colored in green. The three countries above the United States are, in order, Romania, Serbia, and Russia. Below the U.S are the countries, in order, Hungary, Italy, Austria, Ireland, France, and Sweden. The bars decrease in size to indicate the decrease in illiteracy per country.
909.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
909.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

910.title: Enrollment in the Negro common schools of the former slave states of the United States.
910.caption: Enrollment in the Negro common schools of the former slave states of the United States.
910.altText: A horizontal bar chart depicting the number of Black students who attended “common” or public schools between the years 1876 and 1896 in states where, pre-Emancipation, slavery was legal. Each bar is colored in with brown ink and grows in size with each subsequent range of dates listed. The first bar, under the chart’s title and its French translation, indicates 571,506 students attended public schools between 1876 and 1877. The next bar shows that between 1880 and 1881, the number of students who attended public schools increased to 802,374 students. The third bar from the top indicates that 1,048,659 Black students attended common schools from 1885 to 1886. The second to last bar from the bottom shows that, from 1890 to 1891, 1,329,549 students went to public school in the former slave states. The last, longest bar listed indicates that 1,429,713 students attended public school between 1895 to 1896.
910.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
910.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

911.title: Proportion of total Negro children of school age who are enrolled in the public schools.
911.caption: Proportion of total Negro children of school age who are enrolled in the public schools.
911.altText: A bar chart depicting the rising percentage of school-aged Black children who enrolled in public schools every ten years–in 1876, 1886, and 1896. The top section of each bar is colored in red and the bottom in black, with bold black letters showing the percentage of enrollment in each red segment. The leftmost bar is shortest and shows enrollment for 1876 was 37.59%; the middle bar is longer and shows that the enrollment in 1886 rose to 56.66%; and the rightmost bar is the longest of the three and shows that enrollment rose to 57.29% in 1896. A key at the bottom indicates that the red portion of each bar corresponds to “proportion of children enrolled” and the black to “proportion of children not enrolled,” with a French translation under each description.
911.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
911.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

912.title: The Rise of the Negroes from Slavery to Freedom in One Generation
912.caption: The Rise of the Negroes from Slavery to Freedom in One Generation
912.altText: A graphic of two bars comparing the number of enslaved and freed Black folk between the years 1860 and 1890. The bar located in the bottom left corner of the page shows the percentage of those enslaved and freed in 1860 and is divided into a small top section colored in green and a large section on the bottom colored in black. Bold black text within the green component of the bar indicates that 11% of the Black population was categorized as “free laborers,” while bold red text in the black portion indicates that 89% were “slaves.” The second bar, located on the right side of the page, shows the status of Black folk after Emancipation in 1890 and is divided into a small red section at the top and a larger green section that colors in the remainder of the bar. The red portion of the bar details, in black lettering, that 19% of the Black population belonged to a “peasant proprietor” class, or did not own land, while 81% of Black folk, detailed in black lettering in the green section, were tenants. The bar for 1890 is connected to the first 1860 bar by several faded, dotted lines which extend outward from one point along the right edge of the green section of the first bar to many points along the left edge of the green section of the second. The green coloring connects the two bars to indicate the amount of land-owning, free Black men and women exploded within just thirty years, or in one generation. Above the first bar and next to the second, a caption reads: “In 1890 nearly one fifth of them owned their own homes and farms. This advance was accomplished entirely without state aid, and in the face of proscriptive laws,” with a French translation of the sentences below the English text.
912.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33912.
912.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

913.title: Proportion of freemen and slaves among American Negroes.
913.caption: Proportion of freemen and slaves among American Negroes.
913.altText: An area chart comparing the percentage of free to enslaved Black folk in the United States between 1790 and 1870. The proportion depicting free status is colored in green and occupies the top section of the chart, and the proportion for the enslaved is depicted in black and takes up the majority of the chart’s area. The horizontal X axis, which lines the top of the chart, measures ten year increments, and the corresponding percentages of freemen reside in the green space underneath each year, connected by a faint straight line. Also in the green area is bold lettering that reads “Free - Libre,” its French translation. The chart’s momentum flows horizontally, where the green area for the percentage of freemen widens–beginning at 8% in 1790 and oscillating between 11% and 14% for the remainder of the years listed–until green extends the full length of the chart in 1870, post-Emancipation, to signal 100% of Black people were freed. Due to its geometric, abstract structure and green coloring clashing with black, the image resembles a grassy hill that slopes downwards and leads to a cliff.
913.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
913.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

914.title: City and rural population among American Negroes in the former slave states.
914.caption: City and rural population among American Negroes in the former slave states.
914.altText: A horizontal bar chart comparing the percentage of the Black population who lived in cities and rural areas in America’s former slave states every ten years from 1860 to 1890. The key explains that the red portion of each bar indicates the percentage of the Black population that lived in cities (where the population reached or exceeded 8,000 people), and the black portion of each bar shows the percentage of the Black population who lived in villages or country districts. The Black rural population significantly outweighs the Black presence in cities throughout the forty year period: in 1860, 95.8% of Black Americans resided in rural areas compared to 4.2% who lived in cities in the former slave states. The city population grew marginally in ten years, but shifted only by a tenth of a percent between 1870 and 1880–from 8.5% to 8.4% respectively. The last bar shows that the percentage of Black Americans who lived in cities reached 12% in 1890, indicating that 88% still resided in villages or country districts in the former slave states.
914.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
914.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

915.title: Conjugal condition of American Negroes according to age periods.
915.caption: Conjugal condition of American Negroes according to age periods.
915.altText: Part grid and part area chart, this colorful graphic shows the marital status of Black men and women in the United States according to their age. The horizontal X axis measures the percentage (from 0 to 100%) of men and women who are single, married, or widowed, and the vertical Y axis measures age. The age increments from bottom to top, are listed as follows: 0 to 15; 15 to 20; 20 to 25; 25 to 30; 30 to 35; 35 to 45; 45 to 55; 55 to 65; and over age 65. Divided vertically in the middle, the left side of the grid tracks Black men’s marital status, and the right side measures Black women’s. Green space, which indicates widowers, occupies each top corner and falls vertically, serving as a border to the majority of the other categories; red space sits next to the green to show who is married; and blue lies in the center and along the bottom next to the red area to depict those who are single. Because of its near symmetry and vibrancy, the graphic looks like an abstract image of a city at sunset, with the central blue area resembling a silhouetted large building, and the red and green areas on either side of the blue depicting the sky.
