915.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33915.
915.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

916.title: The Amalgamation of the White and Black elements of the population in the United States.
916.caption: The Amalgamation of the White and Black elements of the population in the United States.
916.altText: A chart that shows the increasing number of Black and Black multiracial residents in the United States from 1800 to 1890. Drawn resembling a steep mountaintop, which begins at 1800 on the right of the page and falls to 1890 at the bottom left, the chart’s downward motion emphasizes how the range and scope of blackness shifted during the nineteenth century. To depict what Du Bois labels as the “amalgamation” of the growing number of Black people in the United States and their shifting phenotypes, the chart sections off three discrete racial categories by hue, which lighten gradually from black to white. The Black population is colored in black and implies that this portion of the population showed no visual trace of interracial coupling. To its right, the color grows slightly lighter as it nears what Du Bois labels as the “mulatto” or multiracial population, which is split between a light brown and a dark yellow color to depict the portion of the Black population that announces a white presence in one’s lineage. The white population section is predominately drawn with the paper’s off-white hue, except for a light yellow gradient where it comes into contact with the multiracial population, to its left. There is no quantitative data associated with the white population. While no percentages or numbers are stated in the slimmer sections tracking the 1800s or 1840s, the chart shows that by 1860 the Black population amounted to 3,542,147 people–90% of all Black people in America–and the multiracial population made up the remaining 10% of the total Black population. In 1890, while both grew in size, the Black population decreased to 85% (6,337,980 people) while the Black multiracial population increased to 15% (1,113,063 people).
916.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33916.
916.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

917.title: Assessed value of property owned by Negroes in three states of the United States.
917.caption: Assessed value of property owned by Negroes in three states of the United States.
917.altText: A rectangular graphic separated into four triangles converging at the center detailing the black-owned property value of three states–Georgia, Virginia, and North Carolina–and the total value of all states. The top brown triangle depicts the black-owned property value in Virginia in 1895, which amounted to $13,933,998. The triangle to the left is red and shows that black-owned property value in North Carolina in 1891 totaled $8,018,446. The blue triangle on the right shows that black-owned Georgia property in 1895 was $12,941,230. The bottom triangle is black and depicts the total black-owned property value of all three states in both dollar amount and francs: $34,893,684, or 180,796,290 francs. Because the vertical length of the rectangle graphic is larger than the horizontal width, each rectangle is not proportional to its corresponding property value in relation to the others. For instance, North Carolina and Georgia point towards each other as the triangles on the left and right of the rectangle, but their totals have a difference of over 4 million dollars, even though their triangle dimensions are equal. The same goes for Virginia and the total amount of all three states combined, where Virginia’s brown triangle and the black triangle showing the total of the three point towards each other and have the same dimensions, but have a difference of over 20 million dollars in the black-owned property values they depict.
917.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
917.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

918.title: Negro landholders in various states of the United States.
918.caption: Negro landholders in various states of the United States.
918.altText: A bar chart comparing the percentage of Black landowners to Black renters in nine southern states. The percentage of landowners is not shaded in and always exceedingly less than the percentage of renters, while the fragment of the bar for renters is shaded in black, taking up most of the page. From top to bottom, the states and their respective percentages of Black landowners are as follows: Virginia, 27% landowners; South Carolina, 18% landowners; Texas, 22% landowners; North Carolina, 19% landowners; Georgia, 12% landowners; Mississippi, 13% landowners; Tennessee, 20% landowners; Louisiana, 125 landowners; Arkansas, 21% landowners.
918.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
918.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

919.title: Negro business men in the United States.
919.caption: Negro business men in the United States.
919.altText: A graphic of differently sized and colored squares, which looks less like a chart and more like an abstract geometric painting, alludes to the varying amounts of Black men who worked in different occupations. The estimated capital of each combined job is listed on the top of the chart as $8,784,637 or 45,518,254 francs. Each square is connected to a thin line of the same color to where the title of the occupation is listed vertically on the left side of the page, in English and with a French translation underneath. The first category of work relates to those who worked in general merchandise stories, connected to a wide green rectangle that is the second-largest shape on the page. Underneath it is a large yellow rectangle that is as wide as the green one but much longer, depicting the amount of Black men who worked as grocers. Next is a small red square–the smallest shape of the graphic–that stands in for the amount of men who worked as bankers. A larger blue rectangle, about half the size of the green rectangle for those who worked in general merchandise stores, follows the small red square to depict the amount of men who worked as undertakers. A wide black rectangle falls underneath the blue rectangle to represent men who worked as building contractors. The next occupation is listed as “druggists,” and a brown line runs underneath the black rectangle and down below the yellow grocers shape to connect to a brown square, smaller than the blue above, depicting the amount of men who worked as pharmacists. A large green square of similar dimensions as the blue building contractors shape follows to represent the amount of Black men who worked as publishers. Lastly, a red line stretches underneath the green square and connects to a wide red rectangle, about twice the size of the other small red square, that depicts the amount of men who served as building and loan associates.
919.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
919.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

920.title: Pauperism among American Negroes.
920.caption: Pauperism among American Negroes.
920.altText: Part circle chart and part bar chart, this graphic shows the amount of Black men and women who are poor or “paupers” compared to those who are not. A large brown semicircle takes up the bulk of the page to describe, as the chart says under the title, the “proportion of almshouse paupers in every 100,000 negroes.” Along the bottom edge of the large brown semicircle, which represents 100,000 Black people, a small red semicircle appears, depicting 86 paupers. From the red semicircle, a bar graph is drawn below to show the ratio of Black men–colored in green–compared to women–colored in yellow–who made up those 86 individuals. The green section stretches slightly farther than the yellow, indicating more men than women of those 86 people were in almshouses.
920.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
920.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

921.title: Mortality of American Negroes.
921.caption: Mortality of American Negroes.
921.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
921.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

922.title: Crime among American Negroes.
922.caption: Crime among American Negroes.
922.altText: A long rectangle, displayed at a forty-five degree angle, is divided into five color blocks to show the various crimes 3,250 Black prisoners committed. The first category listed, corresponding to the topmost sliver of the rectangle, is red to describe crimes against the government. This red slice is the smallest of the graphic. Crimes against society are listed next and colored in yellow, a substantially larger block than the red. Larger still is the next block, colored in brown, to depict crimes against individual persons. The largest block of the rectangle is next and colored in black, nearly twice the size of the brown block, to show crimes Black people committed against property. The final category is colored in green and represents miscellaneous crimes, which is slightly smaller than the yellow category for crimes against society.
922.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
922.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.

924.title: Religion of American Negroes.
924.caption: Religion of American Negroes.
924.altText: A bar chart showing the Christian religious affiliations of Black people in the United States. The top two categories stretch to twice the height of the remaining bars, showing the number of Catholics compared to Protestants, which are depicted in red and green, respectively. Though pronounced due to its color, the red bar is merely a sliver, showing 14,517 Catholics, while the green bar runs the width of the paper and curls up and over twice, like a blocky spiral, to indicate the vast number of people who were Protestants in comparison, which amounted to 2,659,460 people. Five yellow bars of smaller height follow the red and green to represent the amount of Black people within the different Protestant sects. No concrete numbers are attached to these yellow bars, and length is relied upon to imply comparative amounts. The topmost yellow bar for Baptists stretches the entire width of the page, and the second yellow bar for Methodists reaches just short of the page’s width. The last three yellow bars–depicting Presbyterians, Congregationalists, and those of miscellaneous affiliation, in that order–are strikingly shorter. The bar for Congregationalists is only a slice of yellow, barely perceptible, while the bars for Presbyterians and miscellaneous are small squares of yellow.
924.creditLine: Image courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, LC-DIG-ppmsca-33865.
924.digitizedLine: Digitized by the Library of Congress.
